title: Thursday, 28th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

Good to see a number of you at the RabbleFest last night

PM11:01am

I feel suitably damaged this morning

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Which means Bryce is going to do most of the typing today

PM11:02am

But first...

PM11:02am

Viktor Shvets

11:02 am
PM11:02am

He's a new one to me

PM11:02am

Global head of equity strategy at Macquarie

PM11:03am

Bringing us stuff like this

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Bear with

PM11:03am

Grey in full

PM11:03am

In this issue we ask whether cryptocurrencies are just a passing fad and whether anything can replace US$ as store of value and medium of exchange.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

yes, really

BE11:03am

..... okay.

PM11:03am

When a number of financial executives recently described Bitcoin as a “fraud” akin to the tulip mania, it exhibited their apparent lack of appreciation of fundamental shifts that are altering global monetary and financial systems. If one describes Bitcoin as a fraud, how would one describe a ‘financial cloud’ that is at least 4x-5x larger than the underlying economies? It is unlikely that US$400 trillion+ of financial instruments circulating around the world would ever be repaid and most are now backed by assets that are already either worthless or are diminishing in value. How does one describe rates and the yield curve that are either directly determined by CBs (BoJ or PBoC) or heavily influenced by them (Fed or ECB)? People living in glass houses should not throw stones.

11:03 am
PM11:04am

We view cryptocurrencies as a response to a world where business and capital cycles are micromanaged by state agencies, with the single most important price (cost of money) determined by CBs, thus precluding price discovery. State- derived prices lead to ‘black market’ economies as the only means of reflecting pressures that are otherwise suppressed. In extremes, it ultimately leads to barter economies. In the 1920s, the US prohibition made liquor more valuable than dollars, while in the mid-’90s, Russian factories traded tanks or missiles for potatoes, and a similar barter system prevails today in Congo, Cuba and Venezuela. As potatoes kept value better than tanks, cryptocurrencies are perceived to be outside the state-controlled system. While we do not pass a judgement as to the value of Bitcoin, we view cryptocurrencies as a natural outgrowth of an over-financialized fiat-based monetary system. Fintech that enables cryptocurrencies is currently rewiring the entire global monetary system. It reduces costs but threatens to disintermediate banks (commercial & CBs).

BE11:04am

Cripes!

PM11:04am

There's more

11:04 am
PM11:04am

However, some argue that if cryptocurrencies impinge upon the ability of CBs to manage liquidity, they can just ban them. This is true, but it ignores fundamental reasons as to why these alternatives appeared in the first place, which would remain valid, irrespective of state actions. If Bitcoin is banned or restricted, a new alternative will arise. Why not seashells? Seashell Beach in WA has been rated as the place with the most abundant supply of some of the best seashells; perhaps Perth could become the new global CB. What about gold? Although it is incompatible with ongoing financialization, gold is far from a ‘barbarous relic’ and is highly likely to maintain its attractiveness. What if gold is also banned? Then other barter swaps would emerge. Indeed, the world of the Information Age is increasingly one of commons, where people already exchange products and services (spare bedroom for a car; book review for coupons). While it does create a major headache for economists, within a decade this sharing is likely to become ubiquitous and perhaps even the dominant form of interactions.

BE11:04am

C r i p e s !

PM11:04am

And here comes Sheena Easton....

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Just as Sheena Easton’s 1981 hit song (Nine to Five) has already passed into ancient history, together with other antiquated concepts, such as middle class, picket fences and career path, the idea that CBs can manage billions of signals is as outdated as the Soviets measuring output by weight. Even with AI-assisted planning, human ingenuity and technology are likely to outsmart planners. Is there a role for cryptocurrencies and gold in investment portfolios? Absolutely. These are insurance policies against degrading of fiat currencies. However, for now, US$ remains the king and until changes to the monetary system become more pronounced (cryptocurrencies account for ~0.5% of cash in circulation), economies would continue to reside on a de-facto US$ standard.

PM11:05am

Actually, there's another 14 pages of that

BE11:05am

C r i p e s !

11:05 am
PM11:05am

And to repeat, this chap is global head of equity strategy at Macquarie

BE11:05am

C r i p e s !

PM11:05am

Ive usual placed it

11:05 am
BE11:05am

I can only note that Hong Kong is 33 degrees and 80% humidity right now.

BE11:06am

That must have an effect on a man.

PM11:06am

Let me get a pic of the chap

11:06 am
PM11:06am

BE11:06am

Steady.

PM11:06am

Of sorry, wrong one

11:06 am
PM11:06am

BE11:07am

Though, having used the Hong Kong mitigation, CLSA has an entirely sensible bitcoin thing out this morning.

PM11:07am

Oh, go on!

11:07 am
BE11:08am

From its annual "Theorality" series, which is kind of a wrap of what you should be thinking, for those who struggle to generate independent thought.

PM11:08am

Useful

BE11:08am

The gist is pretty straightforward. As in, decentralised currencies are nice in theory but, in practice, it's a bit risky to kick away the relatively safe foundation of centralised, consensus-based decisions.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Because you end up with forks, schisms, fractures, whatever. And no-one wants to read Reddit messageboards for their central bank guidance.

BE11:09am

It then spools over to blockchain, with the argument that there's plenty of places where multi-party authentication will be useful.

BE11:09am

So .... smart contracts, disintermediation, all that. Or as we used to call them, databases.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

My key sticking point is that anyone can have their own crypto currency. There are currently 1130 here https://coinmarketcap.com/all/views/all/

PM11:10am

But go on

BE11:10am

That's the point. Blockchain for a currency looks very silly. Blockchain as a database is so sensible it's extremely dull.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

That's why things like Hyperledger already exist.

BE11:11am

Databases aren't that exciting.

BE11:11am

I've not seen many futurologists do 50 pages on MySQL vs MongoDB for HDDMS, so am a bit lost as to why blockchain carries this near mythical status.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Have a nice screenshot from CLSA and then let's get on.

BE11:12am

BE11:13am

Actually, have another one as well.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

BE11:13am

..... clearly demonstrating that CLSA = Illuminati.

undefined
11:14 am
BE11:14am

So, back to earth.

BE11:14am

FTSE's flat for about the 19th day running, corporate's a bit thin.

BE11:15am

There's Imperial, I guess.

11:15 am
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,223, down 82 (-2.48%), High: 3,300, Low: 3,213, Volume: 1.23m
BE11:16am

The tobacco maker that thought "Tobacco" was the most troubling part of its name, rather than the "Imperial" bit.

BE11:16am

Trading statement lacks numbers.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

So ....... on track to meet 2017 guidance, H2 performance better than H1, some nonspecific stuff about new launches and an extended footprint in 2018.

BE11:18am

Nothing really changes, which can be seen as slightly disappointing on the basis that the Logista selloff and the pensions rejig have released a decent amount of cash.

BE11:19am

Note that the statement flags up the one-time gain from pension restructuring

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Which looks to be the reason earnings were in line.

BE11:19am

Here's Citi .....

BE11:20am

Imperial is trading on only 11.4x CY18E EPS, which looks very
attractive. However results have been disappointing for several years. We have argued that for the stock to rerate it needs to show that it has returned to sustainable growth. The company says it will grow from FY18 onwards. Unfortunately we do NOT believe this statement is evidence that Imperial has turned the corner. We retain our Neutral rating.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

In 1H17 Imperial’s market share trends got better in many markets, and Growth Brands gained 60bps of share, although total market share was still down. Imperial said these trends have improved further, and it is now gaining share in most of its priority markets, such that overall market share was up in 2H. Unfortunately disappointing price-mix, particularly in France, Russia, and the UK, means that organic sales growth was no better than consensus.

BE11:20am

Imperial flagged that they have mitigated the impact of the weak pricing by accelerating the cost programmes and pension scheme restructurings. In 1H, Imperial restructured the US pension scheme, resulting in a one-off, non-cash $25m gain that boosted adjusted EBIT. In 2H, Imperial has restructured the UK scheme, and we believe this must have resulted in a large gain, as the UK pension scheme is bigger. Without these one-time, non-cash gains, it would have missed consensus. Furthermore they create a tough hurdle for FY18 earnings.

BE11:21am

I've seen a figure of £80m bandied about for the one-time pension benefit but haven't had time to confirm that.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Jefferies:

BE11:22am

We have long argued that Imperial is far too cheap and as catalysts come through towards building conviction in the on-going delivery of the model we will see re-rating. Positive commentary around the Logista sale a few weeks back was one such catalyst, and we believe today's update should serve as another. Being "on track" implies a strong second half performance (organic EPS c.6%) comfortably within Imperial's long-term targets (4%-8%). Focus will now turn to the full announcement on November 7th where we believe the shape of delivery (implied share gains, price/mix no worse than expected at half year, AND strong margin development) should support further. The big question for us (and the market, given conversations we have had) at full-year numbers will be expectations for next year. We believe Imperial is now in a strong position to deliver on its model. Confirmation of this, in our view, would act as another hugely positive catalyst. The risk to this scenario, however, (for us) is a growing feeling that Imperial may announce another investment year behind reduced risk (specifically heated tobacco). Our personal view of such a move, and those of a number of investors we have spoken to, would be negative. In addition to the earnings downgrades, we also believe we would see de-rating. We believe there would be both little confidence in the end result of such investment and the lack of visibility on model delivery persists. From conversations we have had with the company post the release, and commentary around just investing further behind Blu in the coming year, we do not see another "investment year" scenario playing out (a positive) and as such, would expect outperformance over the near-term to persist.

BE11:24am

The investment in Blu looks like a fairly strong hint that they'll have something heat-not-burn quite soon, incidentally.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

As in, these bloody stupid things.

BE11:24am
BE11:24am

Why? Whyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy?

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Anyway.

undefined
BE11:25am

Okay, you've probably noticed that Paul's disappeared.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Apologies for the slightly slower typing.

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 291.60, down 12.5 (-4.11%), High: 302.40, Low: 283.20, Volume: 511.89k
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Which is on HSBC

BE11:26am

Who are worried about a pickup in voucher promotions.

BE11:26am

Recent voucher data suggest that while vouchers use is significantly lower than its peak in 2008-2009, there has been a noticeable uptick in promotional activity since the start of 2016, with vouchering in June +60% YoY and the last three months (Jun-Aug 17 vs Jun-Aug 16) +22.6% YoY.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

The chart there is quite something ......

BE11:27am

BE11:27am

...... though I'm not sure what.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And the conclusion is that Restaurant's turnaround isn't going to be quick or easy.

BE11:28am

Management are making the changes to turn the Group around. However, as cost pressures, supply and market promotional activities continue to grow, a quick fix is unlikely. New site openings continue to grow at a 3-4% p.a with smaller brands looking to grow their base. Large operators have turned to vouchers and promotional activities, growing c23% YoY and the full effect of these add to the execution risks for RTN. Given the balance of risks, we expect 2018 to be another year of transition.

BE11:29am

H1 results weren't proof of anything really, it being too early in the rejig, and competition isn't lessening across the estate outside the captive-consumer side of airports ....

11:29 am
BE11:29am

So ..........

BE11:29am

Frankie & Benny’s menu prices have been cut by c7% on average, with larger reductions in entry level dishes along with a revised kid’s offer. Early signs suggest volume growth is coming through from price drops, but this is inadequate to maintain earnings at the same level. We estimate the Group will need to grow volumes by c1.3% for every 1% drop in price for similar orders. Chiquito is going through similar changes, but these haven’t been deployed nationally.

BE11:30am

"Hey kids, we're going to Frankie & Benny's. I've heard the creamy chicken pasta with bacon fixin's is circa 7% cheaper."

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Might happen, I guess.

BE11:31am

We cut our EPS forecasts by c4% in FY17 and c8% in FY18, as cost and competitive pressures suggest a slower recovery. We believe RTN should trade on 12x FY18e EPS, being the average PE rating post the Jan 2016 profit warning, and we derive a target price of 265p. The dividend yield is supporting the shares near term, but we highlight the risk of this being cut as Management “continue to assess the dividend on progress against the plan.” We assume a 2x cover, being the higher end of their cover guidance, which implies a 3.8% yield. Retain Reduce.

undefined
11:31 am
BE11:32am

ROTR deep into Boohoo, I see.

BE11:32am

boohoo.com plc (AIM: BOO), a leading online fashion group, announces that, Carol Kane, Joint Chief Executive Officer, has sold 4,650,000 ordinary shares of 1 pence each ("Ordinary Shares") on 27 September 2017 at an average price of 230.1046p per Ordinary Share.

BE11:33am

Following this transaction, Carol has an interest in 46,330,421 Ordinary Shares, representing approximately 4.04 per cent. of the Company's issued Ordinary Share capital.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

The argument here is always that directors have a small window to sell.

BE11:33am

What with pre-results closed periods and whatnot.

BE11:35am

I'm scanning RNS to find a previous open-market sale by Carol, who is of course joint founder of the business.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Not unreasonable for her to take some cash out, even if that cash is £10m+ and it comes at a slightly awkward time when investors are asking if the core business is running out of road.

BE11:36am

FWIW, the sellside remain supportive. Here's Exane.

BE11:36am

Across 1H Boohoo surpassed revenue expectations fuelled by nascent brand PrettyLittleThing (PLT). As is common in ecommerce, this growth comes with an upfront cost. Raising barriers to entry and replication as it grows, Boohoo is directing controlled investment into a far greater opportunity. This comes at a cost to margins which, judging from yesterday’s 10% share price fall, seems to have unsettled investors. We think this is but a short-term drag and with customer response and KPI’s encouraging, the long-term investment case remains intact.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

This is Simon Bowler. He argues that the near-term margin hit is worth it because Pretty Little Thing is a better business.

BE11:37am

Despite more dilutive new customers PLT achieves similar basket gross profit to Boohoo brand, but enjoys higher order frequency and better conversion. Over time the PLT brand looks far more likely to be margin accretive than dilutive.

BE11:38am

330p target.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Barclays also keen.

BE11:39am

We upgraded Boohoo to Overweight on 6 September. Our thesis was based around estimate momentum, driven particularly by top line trends at PLT. Our faith in PLT revenue trends has proven to be correct. But we have been caught out on the cost needed to drive the growth: we hadn’t factored in the scale of price, promotional and marketing investment, and the (slightly) lowered EBITDA margin guidance is a disappointment vs. our prior thinking (as are non cash P&L items + the tax rate) and we make subsequent downgrades (but were well ahead of consensus). Given the lofty multiple, the stock has been hit. Where do we go from here? The debate turns to whether this is the low for EBITDA margins and earnings momentum will return post peak trading season, or whether this is the start of a margin downgrade cycle with further cost pressure to come. Our view is that the margin weakness is largely a function of mix (PLT and Nasty Gal lower margin) rather than underlying pressure in the core Boohoo brand. The marketing going into PLT has already driven it to impressive scale and we think the same could happen with Nasty Gal. So we think it makes sense to invest in this way. There is room aplenty for these two brands to drive positive estimate revisions in the next 12 months, and with margins reset we are happy to stay OW into peak trading. PT comes down to 260p.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

So ......... what else we got?

BE11:41am

Carillion up again, I see.

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 58.50, up 2.25 (+4.00%), High: 58.50, Low: 54.75, Volume: 4.73m
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Overnight press didn't add much to that rather vague CityAM story that retreadded the "Middle East white knight" theory.

BE11:44am

Though The Times mentioned Al-Futtaim of Dubai in connection with the idea.

BE11:45am

Which is .......... hm. I can only reiterate that the story around Carillion interest has been knocking about since January or February.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And, given the problems it faces, should probably be considered a distraction.

BE11:46am

Here's Numis's preview of what'll be said tomorrow.

BE11:46am

The shock profit warning and much higher level of net debt mean that H1 PBT numbers may be somewhat academic (and something of a guessing game in terms of an actual number) relative to management first real attempt to explain what has gone wrong, and more pertinently, how they propose to fix it. The underlying downgrade across all areas was not a focal point at the time but H1 results will show this damage (NB numbers above exclude exceptionals) and how much of an ask getting to revised FY expectations will be. Shares are uninvestable until management can outline that average net debt is both underpinned and can be reduced, not helped by the fact that at the current share price equity issuance as a solution does not look tenable.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

One could argue that equity issurance looks a bit more tenable the more that vague, unplaceable rumours of a takeover are pushed around.

BE11:47am

But that'd be tinfoil-hat stuff, and we don't lower ourselves to that kind of thing here.

undefined
11:48 am
BE11:48am

More fun from Telit noted on the right.

Telit Communications PLC (TCM:LSE): Last: 179.00, down 11 (-5.79%), High: 185.00, Low: 162.00, Volume: 4.43m
BE11:49am

Big cut to guidance.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Banks showing patience, for now.

BE11:50am

But with the boardroom looking unpopulated and no real clarity on its failings of corporate governance, it's going to be a long road back.

BE11:51am

Here's Berenberg.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Telit has opted to narrow its sales guidance range from
$400m-430m (consensus sits at c$400m) to $390m-400m. This implies a reduction of c2.5% versus previous forecasts. With gross margins under slightly more pressure also, given a continuation of supplying lower margin replacement VoLTE CAT 1 modules, alongside negative operational leverage, our EBITDA estimates fall by a larger quantum at -6%. We are now at the low end of both the sales and EBITDA range for 2017E.

BE11:52am

Following the company’s profit warning in August, and the accompanying breach of banking covenants, investors have become concerned about the company’s relationships with commercial lenders. Telit has announced this morning that it expects to “satisfy all covenants” on 30 September (ie the Q3 covenant test). As a precautionary measure, however, it has received a waiver from these providers. This, in our view, will reassure investors, given the sizeable concerns about these relationships. We would anticipate that the business will try and re-negotiate covenant criteria on a permanent basis when the company formalises a restructuring plan.

BE11:53am

...... so, we await the rescue plan. And more importantly, we await the next update on WTH is the deal with Oozi/Uzi Cats/Katz.

11:53 am
undefined
BE11:55am

Oh, I should have remembered to note SSP after noting Restaurant Group.

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 532.00, up 31.5 (+6.29%), High: 532.00, Low: 506.00, Volume: 507.26k
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Amazing to think they're in the same sector .....

BE11:56am

.... though of course they're not.

BE11:56am

In the same way as WH Smith is not in the same sector to Card Factory.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Numbers are stronger than expected, travel still refuses to weaken.

BE11:57am

Airlines concessions good, rail not so good.

BE11:58am

Barclays can summarise the figures.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

SSP has released an unexpected Pre-Close statement which states that revenue growth for the full year will be +19.3% vs. Barclays 17.3% (company consensus c. 17%). The statement is likely to be well received. The statement updates on 4 areas which are all slightly better than guidance given at Q3. Taken together, based on a mechanical calculation, the statement implies that EBIT for FY17 would be c. £157m (vs. Barclays and Bloomberg consensus of £150m). 1) LFLs in Q4 were slightly better than expected at 3% vs. previous guidance of c. 2%. 2) Net gains were slightly better than expected in Q4, at 8.5%, driven by a stronger performance at Chicago Midway where SSP continued to run the temporary units for the whole quarter and there were no closures for rebranding during the quarter as the company had previously guided to at Q3. We note that the deferral of these closures will impact Net Gains in FY18 now. 3) TFS (SSP’s Indian business) has continued to trade ahead of expectations. 4) FX is expected to be an 8% benefit (vs. previous guidance of 7% (Barclays 7%). Taken together, the net impact of these 4 areas implies c. 2% higher total revenue growth vs. our forecasts. If we mechanically take last 2016 sales of £1,990m and multiple this figure by 19.3%, and assume 50bps of margin expansion in FY17, it implies EBIT of c. £157m. This is c. 5% ahead of Bloomberg consensus.

BE11:58am

And Kepler can tell you why it's too expensive.

BE11:58am

While weak GBP is supporting reported figures, this might be a negative in the medium term, as it would be more expensive for SSP to invest its high domestic cash flows abroad. The stock trades on quite expensive 2018 multiples of 11x EV/EBITDA and 17x EV/EBIT (Autogrill is on 8x and 16x respectively). We move our TP to 485p (DCF 8%, WACC 17x, terminal EV/EBIT) and stick to our Hold rating.

11:58 am
undefined
BE11:59am

@Soundbuy, I haven't read the Inland Homes numbers but I'm sure they're thrilling.

Inland Homes PLC (INL:LSE): Last: 58.00, up 0.498 (+0.87%), High: 58.00, Low: 57.75, Volume: 479.45k
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

WH Ireland covers it.

BE12:00pm

INL’s FY-17A (year to June) results this morning demonstrate that the business continues to develop well and to enjoy a range of meaningful opportunities. PBT of £18.1m (+15%) is c.5% ahead of forecasts, and with the forward order book 47% ahead YoY at £33m (FY-16A: £22.5m), the key point in our view is the growing quantum of the business overall, which is on ever more sites. Net asset value at £130.6m is also well ahead (+12%). Reflecting the positive progress, DPS has been raised 33% to 1.2p (0.9p).

Progress has been broad-based. The land portfolio shows an increased landbank at 6,936 plots – of which nearly a third are consented / enjoy resolution grant consent, and which represents a new level for the group. This compares with 17% in the prior period. Diverse projects include notably the Wilton Park, Beaconsfield, planning application for

BE12:00pm

.... less than 350 homes and commercial development – a £350m GDV scheme overall which also illustrates the long-term nature of INL’s land model builds building value over a period of time as the company works towards maximum value realisation.

A caveat highlighted by the company is the ever-laborious nature of the planning system. However the specific drivers for INL’s brownfield land-based business remain very positive in our view and we retain our Buy rating. A more detailed comment will follow in due course.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

So ...... good. That. Super.

undefined
PM12:01pm

Blimey -- thanks for all that Bryce

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

On that note -- i think we are done

PM12:01pm

Lefevre -- where's that quote from?

PM12:02pm

But we are done for today

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Back tomorrow, 11am sharp.

PM12:02pm

Bye!

BE11:26am

In terms of other movers ....... there's always Restaurant Group.
